HCV infection is second to HBV in causing hepatocellular carcinoma and cirrhosis in Taiwan.
109 The overall anti-HCV prevalence was 5·5% in 1991–92, and HCV RNA was detectable in 68% of people with anti-HCV.
110 Unsafe injections and blood transfusions were the commonest routes of transmission 110, 111 before programmes on safe blood transfusions (after 1992) and harm reduction (after 2005) were introduced to reduce the incidence of HCV. 111, 112
